item.title: Enable and use zRAM instead for swap
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
Patrick:

A different configuration is needed for host versus VMs?

What advantages and disadvantage we’d get wiht zram, zwap,

  • inside VM,
  • on the host operating system?

It’s not so much a question of whether it’s in a VM or on the host, as it is a question of how much RAM there is. zram has the advantages of being totally ephemeral and very fast, but it can only increase available RAM so much. According to zram - Gentoo wiki, zram offers about a 3:1 compression ratio. This doesn’t let you just say “a 4 GB RAM system will act like it has 12 GB”, since you have to account for overhead, but assuming you have 1 GB of uncompressed RAM at any one time and the remainder is compressed, you could expand 4 GB to approximately (3 * 3) + 1 = 10 GB. 3 GB could be expanded to about 7 GB. 2 GB could expand to about 4 GB, which is where you start getting cramped. Moderate-to-light web browsing gets hard at that point.

zswap of course gets around this issue by allowing you to also swap RAM contents out to disk, but that’s much slower and also not totally ephemeral. (Certainly with encryption it’s close to impossible to ever read the RAM contents, but in theory just not saving memory to disk is even more secure.) Also the overhead of encrypting and decrypting swap contents makes things even slower.

Perhaps we could use zswap for systems with <= 2 GB RAM, and zram otherwise?

item.title: Enable and use zRAM instead for swap
item.dc:creator: @nurmagoz
item.description:
Patrick:

hibernate requires swap.

Unsupported feature (by default).

item.title: Disposables read-only
item.dc:creator: @suse211213
item.description:
I have read provided docs.
Ok it answered my first question

But not 2
How securely mount encrypted media on qubes in general against malware and forensic.

Apart from FDE.

But If kicksecure is used as host .everething is understandable

Since per doc
disposable are suited alternative to host live mode
However disposable are not amnesic

Anyhow i will back to kicksecure host .
I don’t see anything special in qubes except networking benefits. Secure host + vbox can do same

item.title: Disposables read-only
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
suse211213:

Install kvm or vbox inside disposable

It stops right there already. → Please read:

Kicksecure – 6 Sep 24

Nested Virtualization

It is possible to run Virtual Machines (VMs) inside other VMs. That is called Nested Virtualization.

specifically Nested Virtualization, Qubes and Security Considerations.

related:

Kicksecure – 2 Nov 24

VM Live Mode: Anti-forensics Precautions

Minimize what is written to the hard drive when using Kicksecure VMs in Live Mode.

item.title: Enable and use zRAM instead for swap
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
• Suspend to RAM (aka suspend)
  • Suspend to disk (aka hibernate)
arraybolt3:

(though I think swap-file-creator is encrypting the swapfile).

Yes.

nurmagoz:

dont think any disk swap is needed in nowadays hardware.

hibernate requires swap.

arraybolt3:

swap-file-creator might be a good place to configure this?

Yes.

arraybolt3:

I personally prefer zram on my systems, however for VMs with only 2 or 3 GB RAM zswap might be more practical.

A different configuration is needed for host versus VMs?

What advantages and disadvantage we’d get wiht zram, zwap,

  • inside VM,
  • on the host operating system?

item.title: Disposables read-only
item.dc:creator: @suse211213
item.description:
Kicksecure – 6 Sep 24

Read-Only: Setting Hard Drives to Read-Only

When using live mode, no changes are made to the disk. For added security, consider setting your disk to read-only mode, if possible.

Install kvm or vbox inside disposable to set disks to read only = immutable to boot second OS inside

Will this increases the security as alternative to host live mode

How securely mount encrypted media on qubes in general against malware and forensic.

Can this considered as another disadvatage of qubes behavour.

item.title: Enable and use zRAM instead for swap
item.dc:creator: @nurmagoz
item.description: Thanks for the input, i see only to use zram, no need for anything else, as i dont think any disk swap is needed in nowadays hardware.

item.title: Enable and use zRAM instead for swap
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
There are a couple aspects to this that need to be explored.

For one, there’s zram and zswap. zram is fully ephemeral - no data in RAM ever touches the disk in any form, encrypted or otherwise. This helps reduce disk wear-and-tear, and could be theoretically useful from a security standpoint. However, it does mean that systems with lower RAM can only get so much out of zram - the amount of stuff you can have in RAM increases, but there’s an upper limit that depends on what kind of data you’re working on.

zswap on the other hand is basically zram and a swapfile combined. Data is compressed in RAM first, and then infrequently used data is swapped out to disk. This gives you speed benefits, and it lets you fit more stuff in your RAM than normal while also allowing you to have the “virtually infinite memory” capabilities of a normal swapfile. However, it’s a bit trickier to configure, and it does end up with memory contents written to disk which could be bad from a security standpoint (though I think swap-file-creator is encrypting the swapfile).

I personally prefer zram on my systems, however for VMs with only 2 or 3 GB RAM zswap might be more practical. swap-file-creator might be a good place to configure this?

item.title: Enable and use zRAM instead for swap
item.dc:creator: @nurmagoz
item.description:
Its enabled by default in fedora and ubuntu, would be good to have it on kicksecure.

As suggested here to be used on SSD, without the need to use swap:

Debian 12: Fighting with OpenSUSE Snapper!

item.title: Ubiquity / LVM / TPM
item.dc:creator: @nurmagoz
item.description:
TPM 1.2 is flawed, deprecated, thus no machine with this type of TPM considered under the radar of “yes i have TPM on my hardware”:

ncsc.gov.uk

ROCA: Infineon TPM and Secure Element RSA Vulnerability Guidance

Guidance for those who want to understand and reduce the impact of the ROCA vulnerability.

https://crocs.fi.muni.cz/public/papers/rsa_ccs17

Rapid7

Microsoft CVE-2017-15361: Vulnerability in TPM could allow Security Feature...

Rapid7's VulnDB is curated repository of vetted computer software exploits and exploitable vulnerabilities.

Mandatory of usage of password/usbkey…etc for TPM: (the no password thing is BS)

English

TPM Sniffing Attacks Against Non-Bitlocker Targets | Secura

Preboot passwords are important when using BitLocker to prevent all kinds of attacks. One of those attacks is the ability to sniff the TPM chip communication and recover the decryption key. This article shows you how to attack Linux disk encryption...

Ars Technica – 3 Aug 21

Trusted platform module security defeated in 30 minutes, no soldering required

Sometimes, locking down a laptop with the latest defenses isn’t enough.

gist.github.com

https://gist.github.com/osy/45e612345376a65c56d0678834535166#what-does-tpm-protect

tpm-rant.md
TPM provides zero practical security
====================================

TPM (Trusted Platform Module) is as useful for preventing real attackers as the TSA is at preventing real terrorists. The architecture is fundamentally flawed and most existing implementations are completely broken. I thought this argument was settled decades ago[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trusted_Computing#Criticism) when "trusted computing" was introduced mostly as a way to provide DRM and ownership capabilities to organizations. It has largely failed to impact the consumer market when it was introduced back in the early 2000s. However, recently there seems to be a movement by certain parties to reintroduce this failed product back to the market. Microsoft argues that in order to use Windows 11, you need TPM 2.0 compatible hardware because[[2]](https://blogs.windows.com/windows-insider/2021/08/27/update-on-windows-11-minimum-system-requirements-and-the-pc-health-check-app/):

> The Trusted Platform Module(TPM) requirement enables Windows 11 to be a true Passwordless operating system, addressing phishing and other password-based attacks that are easier for attackers to execute when the TPM is not present.

Google is trying to force the ideas of "trusted computing" to web browsers[[3]](https://github.com/RupertBenWiser/Web-Environment-Integrity/blob/main/explainer.md) which although does not mention TPM explicitly, describes a design that would fit well into it.

Even Canonical is jumping on the bandwagon by bringing TPM based full-disk-encryption to Ubuntu[[4]](https://ubuntu.com/blog/tpm-backed-full-disk-encryption-is-coming-to-ubuntu) and claims it "eliminates the need for users to manually enter passphrases during boot" which is vacuously true (you also don't need to enter a passphrase if you disable it altogether but that doesn't mean it's any secure) and "eliminate the attacker’s ability to perform offline brute-force attacks against the passphrase" which is just plain false (you can brute force at a much slower speed).
This file has been truncated. show original

Yet TPM must be implemented correctly otherwise will be useless (yeah trusting blindly whoever made it, until an open source hardware for it available)

usenix.org

sec18-han.pdf

728.22 KB

https://support.lenovo.com/us/en/product_security/ps500550-nuvoton-tpm-denial-of-service-vulnerability

item.title: Kicksecure installation: Cannot set timezone. link creation failed, target /usr/share/timezone; link name: /etc/localtime
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: FWIW I have tried two full installations and one “replace partition” installation of Kicksecure-Xfce-17.2.3.7.iso, and have not been able to reproduce this problem.

item.title: Kicksecure installation: Cannot set timezone. link creation failed, target /usr/share/timezone; link name: /etc/localtime
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: Are you using manual partitioning, “replace partition”, or “install alongside” by any chance? If so, could you share with us the partition layout you’re setting?

item.title: Ubiquity / LVM / TPM
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Microsoft BitLocker encryption cracked in just 43 seconds with a $4 Raspberry Pi Pico

According to the researcher, targeted attacks can bypass BitLocker’s encryption by directly accessing the hardware and extracting the encryption keys stored in the computer’s Trusted Platform Module (TPM) via the LPC bus.

Breaking Bitlocker - Bypassing the Windows Disk Encryption

  • GitHub - stacksmashing/pico-tpmsniffer: A simple, very experimental TPM sniffer for LPC bus

Hardware dependent.

Maybe would be less of an issue if the TPM was integrated inside the CPU (because nobody can disassemble a CPU, not even Intel / TSMC):

Quote https://www.reddit.com/r/intel/comments/1b3z5s4/where_is_the_tpm_physically_located/

TPM is usually on the motherboard. otherwise TPP would be listed in the specs of the cpus on intels site.

That comment makes seems helpful. If TPM was integrated inside the CPU, it would be mentioned in the specification of the CPU.

Maybe better with AMD fTPM and Intel PTT (Platform Trust Technology).

www.guru3d.com – 3 May 23

Researchers Expose Vulnerabilities in AMD's Firmware-Based TPMs

In their recent paper, "faulTPM: Exposing AMD fTPMs' Deepest Secrets," researchers at the Technical University of Berlin have highlighted a new exploit targeting AMD's firmware-based Tru...

item.title: Kicksecure installation: Cannot set timezone. link creation failed, target /usr/share/timezone; link name: /etc/localtime

item.description: We might need the log to be able to debug this. Please provide.

item.title: Kicksecure installation: Cannot set timezone. link creation failed, target /usr/share/timezone; link name: /etc/localtime
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
related:

github.com/calamares/calamares

Cannot set timezone. Link creation failed, target: /usr/share/zoneinfo/America/New_York; link name: /etc/localtime

opened 02:40PM - 27 Sep 19 UTC
closed 09:46AM - 08 Oct 19 UTC
kevinsmia1939

So I create a live ISO with openSUSE's Kiwi The live ISO use openSUSE Tumblewee…d repo with KDE DE I include Calamares as one of the package in the live ISO I start Calamares with sudo -E calamares -d The installation procedures is nothing special, Select language English (which is the default) Select timezone default (america, newyork ) The partition table was selected as "Erase all" with EXT4 After confirm to install the error message popup ``` Cannot set timezone. Link creation failed, target: /usr/share/zoneinfo/America/New_York; link name: /etc/localtime ``` I tried delete /etc/localtime and try again, same error. item.title: Kicksecure installation: Cannot set timezone. link creation failed, target /usr/share/timezone; link name: /etc/localtime
item.dc:creator: @Mutaz
item.description: I have a problem installing the KickSecure version… Every time I reach the penultimate stage, it shows me: timezone failed. I tried my region and more than one region, but it was not resolved.

item.title: Randomized hostname protocol
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Updated wiki a bit just now.

suse211213:

Hostname aren’t sent by default due to missing /etc/hostname

Just because /etc/hostname doesn’t mean that there isn’t any hostname. Type:

hostname

result:

sys-net

If it’s sent or not needs different evidence.

item.title: Randomized hostname protocol
item.dc:creator: @suse211213
item.description:
Whonix – 4 Mar 24

MAC Address

MAC Address Spoofing and Tracking Threats

I think this would be edited ?
Latest Qubes sys-net do randomize mac by default .
Hostname aren’t sent by default due to missing /etc/hostname

hostname randomization section

It isn’t necessary to randomize the hostname when one can simply not leak it

I would revert this, allow sent it after its randomized.

Note: wont open new thread in qubes section due to relation to this topic

item.title: Kicksecure as Server OS?
item.dc:creator: @mmap
item.description:
Could we make D-I install only the kicksecure-cli(-host) meta package?

We can add the kicksecure source list as a late_command or early_command in preseed config. Something like this:

d-i preseed/late_command string \ 
in-target sh -c 'echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/derivative.asc] https://deb.kicksecure.com bookworm main contrib non-free" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/derivative.list';

And then install the package after update:

d-i preseed/late_command string \ 
    in-target apt-get update; \
    in-target apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends kicksecure-cli-host

item.title: Kicksecure as Server OS?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
related:

Debian Installer (`D-I`) Development
Thanks to @arraybolt3 in the next release of Kicksecure 17.2.3.9 and above, it will be possible to use D-I (Debian-Installer - Wikipedia, the “console looking” Debian installer) (not calamares!). references: Preseed - Wikipedia https://wiki.debian.org/DebianInstaller DebianInstaller/FAQ - Debian Wiki Preseed - Wikipedia What this is not? This is not calamares.

item.title: Debian Installer (`D-I`)
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Thanks to @arraybolt3 in the next release of Kicksecure 17.2.3.9 and above, it will be possible to use D-I (Debian-Installer - Wikipedia, the “console looking” Debian installer) (not calamares!).

references:

en.wikipedia.org

Debian-Installer

Debian-Installer is a system installer for Debian and its derivatives. It originally appeared in Skolelinux (Debian-Edu) 1.0, released in June 2004, but is now used as the official installation system since Debian 3.1 (Sarge), which was released on June 6, 2005. Debian-Installer consists of two modes: a text mode and a graphical mode. Multiple components of the installer exists to configure various aspects of the installed system, and configuration of some components may require user input. Reg...

  • Preseed - Wikipedia
  • https://wiki.debian.org/DebianInstaller
  • https://wiki.debian.org/DebianInstaller/FAQ
  • Preseed - Wikipedia

What this is not? This is not calamares.

en.wikipedia.org

Calamares (software)

Calamares is a free and open-source independent and "distribution-agnostic" system installer for Linux distributions. Calamares is used by NixOS, CachyOS, Garuda Linux, Huayra_GNU/Linux, Manjaro, Netrunner, KaOS, KDE neon, Kubuntu, Lubuntu, Sabayon Linux, Chakra, EndeavourOS, Peppermint OS, Artix Linux, OpenMandriva Lx, Q4OS, the Live medium of Debian, and several less known Linux distributions. It also has been used to automate the installation of command line distributions and to make custom d...

D-I is somewhat a “by-product” of switching to build the ISO using Debian live-build (which was done to fix some booting related issues).

Not much (none at time of writing) D-I related development is planned. Main focus will remain Calamares.

item.title: Swap-file-creator missing when in Qubes templates (morphing & official derivative templates)
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
At time of writing (and it’s unlikely this will change), swap-file-creator is for non-Qubes only. (Should that ever change, documentation would be updated.)

swap-file-creator for Qubes is unsupported.

Kicksecure – 12 Oct 24

Undocumented, Untested or Unsupported Features

This feature is either undocumented, untested, or unsupported. Options: Become a Contributor / Apply Self Support First Policy / Purchase Support.

Setting up swap and/or encryption of any kind is completely up to Qubes. Unspecific to Kicksecure.

Kicksecure – 6 Sep 24

Potential Solutions Beyond Kicksecure!

Explore resources outside of Kicksecure to address unspecific questions or issues.

Added to documentation just now.

item.title: Why is the uwt not included in the Kicksecure repository?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description: It’s part of Whonix only. Not part of Kicksecure.

item.title: Why is the uwt not included in the Kicksecure repository?
item.dc:creator: @Quiksilver
item.description:
Why is the uwt package not included in the Kicksecure repository or included with Kicksecure by default?

I went to see if its installed or available to install but its not in the repo.

item.title: Swap-file-creator missing when in Qubes templates (morphing & official derivative templates)
item.dc:creator: @Crok
item.description:
I tend to have a promising idea for digging into something right after posting a question.

apt-cache rdepends swap-file-creator

swap-file-creator
Reverse Depends:
  non-qubes-enhancements-cli
  non-qubes-vm-enhancements-cli

I would interpret this as it being only relevant for non-qubes systems? Can someone point me towards some kind of documentation or explanation why this is?
Is it related to Qubes already being installed on an encrypted disk by default? Wouldn’t there be a benefit from a per-boot encrypted file still, which Qubes has been talking about for something close to a decade?

Just throwing around theories as to why this is, I might be missing something in the related docs.

item.title: Swap-file-creator missing when in Qubes templates (morphing & official derivative templates)
item.dc:creator: @Crok
item.description:
Hi,

I’ve been using Kicksecure and it’s derivatives for a good while by now in Qubes VMs and on servers (Kicksecure in Qubes and on server is morphed, Whonix 17 templates are official Qubes templates) and just realized that I have a seemingly plain, unencrypted swap partition on all Qubes templates. The morphed version on the server host looks correct, if I am not mistaken. Reading the documentation, my impression is that swap-file-creator should change this by default on Kicksecure systems.

Examples:

/etc/fstab entry in morphed Debian template on Qubes OS (click for more details) /etc/fstab entry in my Whonix-Workstation AppVM installed from the official template on Qubes OS (click for more details) Several command outputs from my morphed Kicksecure on a virtual server (click for more details)

The package is also not installed on any of the machines except for the morphed host (actually a VPS). It looks like I chose kicksecure-qubes-cli for the Kicksecure template on Qubes while morphing and, again, the Whonix templates were not built by myself. On the VPS, I chose kicksecure-cli-host. (Writing this… is there potentially a difference between the host and the qubes packages in regards to the package being installed/not installed?)

Trying to find an answer to this still left me with two related questions:

  • Is the documentation outdated? It states that it should be installed by default: /wiki/Swap-file-creator#Installation (posting the link resulted in an error, sorry)
    That said, I don’t know what cases “otherwise” covers or what history, intention or background the sentence has, though.
  • Is there any other countermeasure against potentially sensitive information being written to the disk via swapping, which I was not able to find in the wiki, or may, for instance, keys have ended up on my disk?
Unrelated (click for more details)

item.title: Kicksecure as Server OS?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Thanks to @arraybolt3 in the next release of Kicksecure 17.2.3.9 and above, it will be possible to use D-I (Debian-Installer - Wikipedia, the “console looking” Debian installer) (not calamares!).

Would that help?

It supports preseed (Preseed - Wikipedia) (DebianInstaller/Preseed - Debian Wiki) and whatnot. These are features inherited from D-I.

Could we make D-I install only the kicksecure-cli(-host) meta package? Or would we require a separate headless ISO? Or an option in calamares?

mmap:

And are there any plans to migrate from debian to a more secure distro such as Alpine or Arch?

1 question = 1 forum thread please. This is a much different question than Kicksecure for server.

item.title: Are Tor hidden services on Kicksecure safe against entry-guard attacks?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
NobodyImportant:

but I also seem to have confused the Kicksecure and Whonix design goals.

What’s unclear about Privacy Goals and Non-Goals of Kicksecure?

NobodyImportant:

Since this is an anonymity issue, should I create a topic for this on the Whonix forums instead,

This forum is only about Kicksecure.

And I doubt a new forum thread in Whonix forums is required.

NobodyImportant:

the documentation I referred to seemed to suggest that it once was a feature enabled by default in Whonix,

Right.

NobodyImportant:

but I mistakenly thought that meant that would/should carry into Kicksecure as well.

If “full” vanguards was fixed, maintained upstream (original developers), then maybe Kicksecure could install it by default. Since that isn’t the case, that’s not possible.

NobodyImportant:

but there seems to be the suggestion that since Vanguards Lite is baked into Tor by default

True.

NobodyImportant:

there’s no need to address it as an anonminity issue

The value of “full” vanguards is questionable if not fixed/maintained upstream.

NobodyImportant:

However I am still curious if this is going to end up being something that gets re-enabled with the goal of supporting the anonminity of Whonix users running “long-term” hidden services and if you would rather answer that here than have me create an entirely different topic?

Doesn’t belong into Kicksecure forums.

And no new forum thread in Whonix forums needed either.

  • Would it be nice? Yes, good in theory. But many things would be good in theory but don’t exist either.
  • Is it available? No. Not fixed/maintained upstream.

As long as that is as that, it remains unsupported. What that means and your only options are documented here:

Kicksecure – 12 Oct 24

Undocumented, Untested or Unsupported Features

This feature is either undocumented, untested, or unsupported. Options: Become a Contributor / Apply Self Support First Policy / Purchase Support.

item.title: Kicksecure as Server OS?
item.dc:creator: @nurmagoz
item.description:
mmap:

And @roddhjav pointed out a lot of valid things regarding your review. Most of the things are fixed. Mentioning a 15 year old research paper on package managers is pointless. The UX should be irrelevant or atleast be an afterthought. Most of the people who use whonix and kicksecure are advanced users.

post comments to the same topic of arch, and i pointed out many points not just those who you mentioned.

item.title: Kicksecure as Server OS?
item.dc:creator: @mmap
item.description:
first one failed to be installed on qubes

What do you mean by that? I can install it just fine. Alpine is hardly ever used for desktop anyway.

item.title: Kicksecure as Server OS?
item.dc:creator: @mmap
item.description: And @roddhjav pointed out a lot of valid things regarding your review. Most of the things are fixed. Mentioning a 15 year old research paper on package managers is pointless. The UX should be irrelevant or atleast be an afterthought. Most of the people who use whonix and kicksecure are advanced users.

item.title: Kicksecure as Server OS?
item.dc:creator: @mmap
item.description:
Alpine is no way similar to arch. It has a different init system, uses musl instead of libc just to mention a few significant differences.

its smaller/simpler but doesnt mean more secure

It does imply that they heavily focus on minimalism which does show their commitment to keeping things secure. It’s just one factor.

item.title: Are Tor hidden services on Kicksecure safe against entry-guard attacks?
item.dc:creator: @NobodyImportant
item.description:
Apologies, I appreciate the self-support first policy, but I also seem to have confused the Kicksecure and Whonix design goals. Since this is an anonymity issue, should I create a topic for this on the Whonix forums instead, or would that also be more or less an unsupported feature? I want to clarify because the documentation I referred to seemed to suggest that it once was a feature enabled by default in Whonix, but I mistakenly thought that meant that would/should carry into Kicksecure as well. I have followed some of the discussion about the issue on the Whonix forums, but there seems to be the suggestion that since Vanguards Lite is baked into Tor by default that there’s no need to address it as an anonminity issue. However I am still curious if this is going to end up being something that gets re-enabled with the goal of supporting the anonminity of Whonix users running “long-term” hidden services and if you would rather answer that here than have me create an entirely different topic?

Thanks

item.title: Kicksecure as Server OS?
item.dc:creator: @nurmagoz
item.description:
mmap:

is installing kicksecure on an existing debian efficient?

Thats what morphing is for.

mmap:

What about all the bloat that comes with debian?

Use CD version, which is very minimal or netinstall and install only what you want.

mmap:

And are there any plans to migrate from debian to a more secure distro such as Alpine or Arch?

I reviewed Arch you find it here:

Whonix Forum – 23 Feb 22

Arch Linux Distro Preview

Development

I have been playing with Arch and some their variants (like arcolinux) since like a year, And here is what i have seen: What arch solve: Continues upgrades to the packages which solve debian issues: Solve outdated packages which effect new...

Reading time: 4 mins 🕑 Likes: 9 ❤

Alpine is just similar to arch, not user friendly installation, its smaller/simpler but doesnt mean more secure (something need to be deeply investigated)… so yeah i might give it another try in the future (first one failed to be installed on qubes).

item.title: Error: Plymouth conflict in Debian morphing
item.dc:creator: @sam
item.description: sudo apt install --no-install-recommends kicksecure-xfce-host - Conflict with Plymouth after entering this command when morphing Debian, MX Linux and LMDE. This error was made by me and all my friends. Today, my friend also received it. sudo apt remove plymouth resolves problem. Write about it in morphing instructions so that people know what to do in this situation. It seems that someone has complained about this error on this forum

item.title: Kicksecure as Server OS?
item.dc:creator: @mmap
item.description: And are there any plans to migrate from debian to a more secure distro such as Alpine or Arch?

item.title: Kicksecure as Server OS?
item.dc:creator: @mmap
item.description: I had one more question tho, is installing kicksecure on an existing debian efficient? What about all the bloat that comes with debian?

item.title: Kicksecure as Server OS?
item.dc:creator: @mmap
item.description:
The ISO includes the XFCE environment and the installer seems to be only possible for when you boot using XFCE. Is there no headless installation? Without the use of a bloated DE?

Edit: found the “distro-morphing” method. Sorry for the ping.

item.title: Use Btrfs as the default journaling file system
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
filesystem: “unknown”

Correct, this means go with whatever the default.

Let’s just change the default and avoid adding an extra question?

BTRFS comes with significant additional maintenance needs and benefits from the user having some level of technical expertise. I would be leery of using it as the default. Lubuntu, Kubuntu, and Ubuntu Unity have been shipping with a multi-choice between ext4, BTRFS, and xfs for a while now and no one has reported problems figuring it out (presumably because they stick with the default of ext4 if in doubt). Those who know what they’re doing can change it manually, was my thinking.

item.title: Use Btrfs as the default journaling file system
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
As of Offer BTRFS as a usable filesystem · Kicksecure/live-config-dist@b1d9959 · GitHub it’s

filesystem: "unknown"

Which will as I assume into asking the user if btrfs or ext4.

defaultFileSystemType: "ext4"

Let’s just change the default and avoid adding an extra question? Advanced users are free to use the partition too but I think for most users this is a too confusing, difficult question to decide.

Do we currently have “double swap” issue? swap-file-creator + swap sub volume created by calamares?

item.title: Boot Clock Randomization - Log Inspection
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description: Yes. Documented here: System Logs

item.title: Boot Clock Randomization - Log Inspection
item.dc:creator: @suse211213
item.description:
Thanks.
Is it possible to view all messages during boot sequence afterward?
I saw some warnings after installed ram-wipe but boot messages disappears quickly

item.title: Use Btrfs as the default journaling file system
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Patrick:

Does calamares set up the needed subvolumes yet?

Qutoe @arraybolt3 from calamares - change to BTRFS by default - including subvolumes:

  • Note that Calamares installs BTRFS with subvolumes on the root filesystem by default, so no special work was needed to make that happen.

item.title: Use Btrfs as the default journaling file system
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Does calamares set up the needed subvolumes yet?

arraybolt3:

Getting a snapshotting UI is a bit harder since btrfs-assistant (the only good Snapper frontend I know of) isn’t available in releases older than Trixie.

No problem. Worst case the snapshoting GUI will be introduced after we port to Debian trixie.

arraybolt3:

btrfs-assistant (the only good Snapper frontend I know of)

For reference:

packages.debian.org

Debian -- Details of package btrfs-assistant in trixie

Qt GUI tool to manage Btrfs filesystems

GitLab

Btrfs Assistant / Btrfs Assistant · GitLab

GitLab.com

arraybolt3:

, so I don’t see why we can’t make BTRFS an option for now and then explore further developments with it later.

Indeed.

arraybolt3:

There’s other ways of managing BTRFS snapshots that are worth looking into though,

How about

  • Debian -- Details of package timeshift in bookworm,
  • Debian -- Details of package snapper in bookworm - CLI tool but still useful to install by default?

item.title: Use Btrfs as the default journaling file system
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: Getting Kicksecure to install with BTRFS is pretty easy, almost trivial. Getting a snapshotting UI is a bit harder since btrfs-assistant (the only good Snapper frontend I know of) isn’t available in releases older than Trixie. There’s other ways of managing BTRFS snapshots that are worth looking into though, so I don’t see why we can’t make BTRFS an option for now and then explore further developments with it later.

Fixed in wiki just now.

Boot Clock Randomization

Boot Clock Randomization

item.title: Are Tor hidden services on Kicksecure safe against entry-guard attacks?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Same as Tor on Debian. Nothing special because it’s Kicksecure. Self Support First Policy for Kicksecure applies.

Not development focus for Kicksecure. As per:

Kicksecure – 15 Oct 24

Privacy Goals and Non-Goals of Kicksecure

An overview of the privacy goals and non-goals of Kicksecure, emphasizing its focus on security over privacy and anonymity.

Therefore this is unsupported.

Kicksecure – 12 Oct 24

Undocumented, Untested or Unsupported Features

This feature is either undocumented, untested, or unsupported. Options: Become a Contributor / Apply Self Support First Policy / Purchase Support.

only this worked

sudo journalctl -b --no-pager -u bootclockrandomization

item.title: Boot Clock Randomization - Log Inspection
item.dc:creator: @suse211213
item.description:
If Kicksecure will be with tor disabled as base host
sdwdate will be disabled too

then how to monitor Boot Clock Randomization

mousepad /var/log/bootclockrandomization.log
nano /var/log/bootclockrandomization.log

shows empty text
what should these command outputs
